text: In a Turing model is there a distinction made between the "prior" and the "likelihood"?

elements.text: In a Turing model is there a distinction made between the "prior" and the "likelihood"?

text:
In general, with any Bayesian model, the prior is a distribution over one or more parameters. The likelihood is a distribution over the data given some parameter values. The posterior = likelihood x prior, or log posterior = log likelihood + log prior.

Formally:
P(theta | X) = P(X | theta)P(theta)

P(X | theta) is the likelihood, P(theta) is the prior, P(theta | X) is the posterior.

As far as I know, Turing follows all of the standard terminology here.

text: I'm not sure what exactly you're after. A Turing model with fixed arguments (as e.g. in a `Model` instance that you obtain by instantiating your model) allows you to evaluate stuff like `logprior`, `loglikelihood`, and `logjoint`. However, in general it can't be deduced from the model that you implement with `@model` since it is not fixed what are observations and what are latent variables - if you pass `missing` as one of the arguments an observation becomes a random variable.
